By automating disaster prediction and early warning, nonprofits and local governments could:

  • Reduce disaster response time by up to 60% through real-time alerts.
  • Protect lives and assets by warning communities before extreme weather events occur.
  • Empower NGOs with accurate, data insights to allocate resources efficiently.
  • Strengthen resilience in climate-vulnerable regions using predictive technology.

In measurable terms, EcoAlert System could help thousands of people from being caught unprepared each year and reduce property and crop losses through proactive risk management.
x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement:
Communities around the world face increasing threats from environmental disasters such as floods, landslides, and extreme weather events. Many local nonprofits, councils, and disaster response teams lack real-time tools to monitor environmental risks or send timely alerts.
As a result:
Early warning signs often go unnoticed, Communication with vulnerable populations is delayed, Response efforts become reactive instead of preventive.
This leads to avoidable loss of lives, property, and agricultural damage, especially in under-resourced or rural areas where manual monitoring is still common.

x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

EcoAlert System would be a ServiceNow powered AI automation platform that integrates environmental data (such as rainfall, river levels, and temperature) from public APIs and triggers early alerts to the relevant stakeholders.

How It Works:

  1. Data Ingestion: ServiceNow pulls data from weather APIs (e.g., OpenWeather, Copernicus, or UK Met Office).

  2. AI & Predictive Intelligence: Machine learning models detect risk thresholds (e.g., flood likelihood, high wind speeds).

  3. Workflow Automation:

Automatically creates an incident or “alert record.”

Sends notifications via email, SMS, or chatbot to NGOs and community responders.

4. Dashboards & Reports: ServiceNow Performance Analytics visualizes current risk areas and trends over time.

ServiceNow Products / Capabilities to Use:

  • App Engine: to build the EcoAlert System application and workflows.
  • Flow Designer: to automate data triggers and alert notifications.
  • Predictive Intelligence: for AI based pattern detection and disaster prediction.
  • IntegrationHub: to connect with external weather and GIS APIs.
  • Performance Analytics / Dashboards: to monitor alerts and visualize trends.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

External Weather and Environmental APIs (e.g., OpenWeatherMap, NASA Earth Data, or Met Office API).

SMS or Notification Service Integration (e.g., Twilio, WhatsApp API, or ServiceNow’s Virtual Agent).

Geospatial Mapping Tools (optional) for displaying affected areas visually.

Cloud Hosting / ServiceNow Instance Access for real time processing.

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Data Accuracy & Coverage: Public weather APIs may not always offer high resolution data for remote regions.

Integration Complexity: Connecting multiple external APIs and ensuring consistent data formatting.

Model Training: Developing accurate AI thresholds for predicting floods or storms requires historical data.

User Adoption: NGOs and local governments may need training to interpret alert dashboards effectively.

Connectivity Issues: In rural or disaster affected areas, lack of internet or mobile access may delay alerts.
